articles.headline: The Coin That Could Wreck Crypto
articles.snippet: As cryptocurrencies have plunged, attention has focused on a potential point of vulnerability: the market’s reliance on a so-called stablecoin called Tether.
articles.abstract: As cryptocurrencies have plunged, attention has focused on a potential point of vulnerability: the market’s reliance on a so-called stablecoin called Tether.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Cryptocurrency prices are plummeting. A so-called stablecoin lost all its value in a matter of days. A newfangled crypto bank halted withdrawals. And investors have been plunged into financial ruin.

articles.headline: A Defiant Putin Says Russia Will Flourish Without the West
articles.snippet: In a speech at an economic forum, he called the U.S. a fading power and said sanctions on Russia, not the Ukraine war, are hurting Western economies.
articles.abstract: In a speech at an economic forum, he called the U.S. a fading power and said sanctions on Russia, not the Ukraine war, are hurting Western economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, seeking to rally anti-American sentiment in Europe and across the world, lashed out anew at the United States on Friday, calling it a fading power that treats its allies as colonies, and said the West was falsely blaming its economic woes on the war in Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: The Watergate Hearings, 50 Years Ago: Truth Was Not Up for Debate
articles.snippet: On the anniversary of the June 17, 1972, break-in, alumni of the hearings gather for a reunion. They had it easier than the Jan. 6 committee, they say.
articles.abstract: On the anniversary of the June 17, 1972, break-in, alumni of the hearings gather for a reunion. They had it easier than the Jan. 6 committee, they say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the grandly marbled space of the Russell Senate Office Building known as the Kennedy Caucus Room, where a bipartisan select committee held nationally televised hearings to investigate the burglary of the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate a half-century ago, alumni of that inquiry gathered Friday evening to reminisce — and issue warnings.

articles.headline: Amid Jan. 6 Revelations, Election Lies Still Dominate the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The hearings have demolished the myth of a stolen presidential election, but with the 2022 primary season in full tilt, the revelations have not loosened the grip of the lie on Republicans.
articles.abstract: The hearings have demolished the myth of a stolen presidential election, but with the 2022 primary season in full tilt, the revelations have not loosened the grip of the lie on Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was all a lie, the tales of stuffed ballot drop boxes, rigged voting machines, and constitutional “flexibility” that would have allowed Vice President Mike Pence to nullify the 2020 election results and send them back to Republican state legislatures.

articles.headline: The Rush to E.S.G., With or Without Elon Musk
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk trashed E.S.G. investing. The S.E.C. is investigating Goldman Sachs’s move into the sector. In a falling market, what should investors consider?
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk trashed E.S.G. investing. The S.E.C. is investigating Goldman Sachs’s move into the sector. In a falling market, what should investors consider?
articles.lead_paragraph: Any time the stock market falls, investors are likely to rethink nearly everything.

articles.headline: French Nuclear Power Crisis Frustrates Europe’s Push to Quit Russian Energy
articles.snippet: France typically exports electricity, but now it risks blackouts and a need for imported power because of problems at the state nuclear operator.
articles.abstract: France typically exports electricity, but now it risks blackouts and a need for imported power because of problems at the state nuclear operator.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Plumes of steam towered above two reactors recently at the Chinon nuclear power plant in the heart of France’s verdant Loire Valley. But the skies above a third reactor there were unusually clear — its operations frozen after the worrisome discovery of cracks in the cooling system.

articles.headline: Gun Sellers’ Message to Americans: Man Up
articles.snippet: The number of firearms in the U.S. is outpacing the country’s population, as an emboldened gun industry and its allies target buyers with rhetoric of fear, machismo and defiance.
articles.abstract: The number of firearms in the U.S. is outpacing the country’s population, as an emboldened gun industry and its allies target buyers with rhetoric of fear, machismo and defiance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last November, hours after a jury acquitted Kyle Rittenhouse of two shooting deaths during antiracism protests in 2020, a Florida gun dealer created an image of him brandishing an assault rifle, with the slogan: “BE A MAN AMONG MEN.”
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire, Glenn Thrush and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Despite Growing Evidence, a Prosecution of Trump Would Face Challenges
articles.snippet: As House hearings highlighted testimony that could create more pressure to pursue a criminal case, the former president tried out a defense that strained credulity.
articles.abstract: As House hearings highlighted testimony that could create more pressure to pursue a criminal case, the former president tried out a defense that strained credulity.
articles.lead_paragraph: As new questions swirled this past week about former President Donald J. Trump’s potential criminal exposure for seeking to overturn the 2020 election, Mr. Trump issued a rambling 12-page statement.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Why a Rhodes Scholar’s Ambition Led Her to a Job at Starbucks
articles.snippet: Jaz Brisack became a barista for the same reasons that talented young people have long chosen their career paths: a mix of idealism and ambition.
articles.abstract: Jaz Brisack became a barista for the same reasons that talented young people have long chosen their career paths: a mix of idealism and ambition.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Loopholes and Missing Data: The Gaps in the Gun Background Check System
articles.snippet: The massive system already has major loopholes advocated by gun manufacturers to maintain easier access to firearms. The Senate’s proposed gun reform measures could fall victim to those same limitations.
articles.abstract: The massive system already has major loopholes advocated by gun manufacturers to maintain easier access to firearms. The Senate’s proposed gun reform measures could fall victim to those same limitations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bipartisan gun control bill being hashed out in the Senate this weekend leans heavily on a muscular but mistake-plagued bureaucratic workhorse familiar to any American who has bought a firearm recently: the federal background check system.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Gustavo Petro Wins the Election, Becoming Colombia’s First Leftist Leader
articles.snippet: The former rebel and longtime senator’s victory sets the third largest nation in Latin America on a sharply new path.
articles.abstract: The former rebel and longtime senator’s victory sets the third largest nation in Latin America on a sharply new path.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — For the first time, Colombia will have a leftist president.

articles.headline: When Customers Say Their Money Was Stolen on Zelle, Banks Often Refuse to Pay
articles.snippet: Federal law requires banks to reimburse customers for unauthorized electronic transfers, but they often refuse, stranding victims.
articles.abstract: Federal law requires banks to reimburse customers for unauthorized electronic transfers, but they often refuse, stranding victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: Argelys Oriach was on his way home from a shopping trip one evening in March when he was robbed at gunpoint. The thief demanded his iPhone and passcode. Mr. Oriach turned them over and fled.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Lananh Nguyen

articles.headline: With Roe Set to End, Many Women Worry About High-Risk Pregnancies
articles.snippet: Most states likely to outlaw abortions allow for exceptions to save a mother’s life. But many women and doctors ask: Where will lawmakers draw the line?
articles.abstract: Most states likely to outlaw abortions allow for exceptions to save a mother’s life. But many women and doctors ask: Where will lawmakers draw the line?
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the latest abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

articles.headline: China’s Once-Sizzling Property Market Has Started to Cool
articles.snippet: New home prices in China have fallen, and would-be buyers are thinking twice. That’s bad news for the overall economy.
articles.abstract: New home prices in China have fallen, and would-be buyers are thinking twice. That’s bad news for the overall economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, business was humming for Liang Jiawei, a property salesman in Zhanjiang, a coastal city in southern China.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Joy Dong

articles.headline: Google Says It’s Time for Longtime Small-Business Users to Pay Up
articles.snippet: Google is charging some small businesses for email and other apps after more than a decade of free use. Business owners say Google is being callous.
articles.abstract: Google is charging some small businesses for email and other apps after more than a decade of free use. Business owners say Google is being callous.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Google told some small businesses in January that they would no longer be able to use a customized email service and other workplace apps for free, it felt like a broken promise for Richard J. Dalton Jr., a longtime user who operates a scholastic test-prep company in Vancouver, British Columbia.

articles.headline: Red Flags for Forced Labor Found in China’s Car Battery Supply Chain
articles.snippet: Ties to potentially coercive labor practices could prove a problem for an industry that is heavily dependent on China, once a new law barring Xinjiang products goes into effect.
articles.abstract: Ties to potentially coercive labor practices could prove a problem for an industry that is heavily dependent on China, once a new law barring Xinjiang products goes into effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: The photograph on the mining conglomerate’s social media account showed 70 ethnic Uyghur workers standing at attention under the flag of the People’s Republic of China. It was March 2020 and the recruits would soon undergo training in management, etiquette and “loving the party and the country,” their new employer, the Xinjiang Nonferrous Metal Industry Group, announced.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Failed Autopsies, False Arrests: A Risk of Bias in Death Examinations
articles.snippet: Disastrous errors by medical examiners have raised questions about whether they are influenced by prejudgments and a close relationship with the police.
articles.abstract: Disastrous errors by medical examiners have raised questions about whether they are influenced by prejudgments and a close relationship with the police.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: In a Town Crippled by Grief, the Healing Power of a Perfect Pitch
articles.snippet: Uvalde, Texas, was set to cancel its Little League All-Star Championship after a school shooting left 21 people dead. Then, the decision was made: The games would go on.
articles.abstract: Uvalde, Texas, was set to cancel its Little League All-Star Championship after a school shooting left 21 people dead. Then, the decision was made: The games would go on.
articles.lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — Young people in their crisp Little League uniforms ran up and down the field in giddy anticipation. The smell of nacho cheese and sizzling chicken fajitas spread through the bleachers on the hot summer night breeze.
